raw_text:
Gardener wins double in Glasgow
 
 Britain's Jason Gardener enjoyed a double 60m success in Glasgow in his first competitive outing since he won 100m relay gold at the Athens Olympics.
 
 Gardener cruised home ahead of Scot Nick Smith to win the invitational race at the Norwich Union International. He then recovered from a poor start in the second race to beat Swede Daniel Persson and Italy's Luca Verdecchia. His times of 6.61 and 6.62 seconds were well short of American Maurice Greene's 60m world record of 6.39secs from 1998. "It's a very hard record to break, but I believe I've trained very well," said the world indoor champion, who hopes to get closer to the mark this season. "It was important to come out and make sure I got maximum points. My last race was the Olympic final and there was a lot of expectation. "This was just what I needed to sharpen up and get some race fitness. I'm very excited about the next couple of months."
 
 Double Olympic champion
 
 marked her first appearance on home soil since winning 1500m and 800m gold in Athens with a victory. There was a third success for Britain when
 
 edged out Russia's Olga Fedorova and Sweden's Jenny Kallur to win the women's 60m race in 7.23secs. Maduaka was unable to repeat the feat in the 200m, finishing down in fourth as
 
 took the win for Russia. And the 31-year-old also missed out on a podium place in the 4x200m relay as the British quartet came in fourth, with Russia setting a new world indoor record. There was a setback for Jade Johnson as she suffered a recurrence of her back injury in the long jump. Russia won the meeting with a final total of 63 points, with Britain second on 48 and France one point behind in third.
 
 led the way for Russia by producing a major shock in the high jump as he beat Olympic champion Stefan Holm into second place to end the Swede's 22-event unbeaten record.
 
 won the triple jump with a leap of 16.87m, with Britain's Tosin Oke fourth in 15.80m.
 
 won the men's pole vault competition with a clearance of 5.65m, with Britain's Nick Buckfield 51cm adrift of his personal best in third. And
 
 won the women's 800m, with Britain's Jenny Meadows third. There was yet another Russian victory in the women's 400m as
 
 finished well clear of Britain's Catherine Murphy. Chris Lambert had to settle for fourth after fading in the closing stages of the men's 200m race as Sweden's
 
 held off Leslie Djhone of France. France's
 
 won the men's 400m, with Brett Rund fourth for Britain.
 
 took victory for Sweden in the women's 60m hurdles ahead of Russia's Irina Shevchenko and Britain's Sarah Claxton, who set a new personal best. Italy grabbed their first victory in the men's 1500m as
 
 kicked over the last 200 metres to hold off Britain's James Thie and France's Alexis Abraham. A botched changeover in the 4x200m relay cost Britain's men the chance to add further points as France claimed victory.
llama3.2:1b: Britain's Jason Gardener won two events at the Norwich Union International, including a double gold medal in the 100m and 60m races. He beat Sweden's Daniel Persson and Italy's Luca Verdecchia in both events, with times of 6.61 and 6.62 seconds respectively.
llama3.2:3b: Jason Gardener won double 60m gold at the Norwich Union International, beating Nick Smith and Daniel Persson. Meanwhile, Sharron Maduaka won women's 60m gold with a time of 7.23secs, while Russia dominated the men's events, including high jump, triple jump, pole vault and 400m. Britain took podium places in some events but struggled in others due to injury setbacks and mistakes.
gemma2:2b: Jason Gardener won the 60m at the Norwich Union International, followed by a second victory in the 2nd race.  Great Britain dominated in the women’s events with Dina Asher-Smith and others winning their respective races. Russia took top honors overall. Notable performances included a surprise high jump win for Sergey Shubenkov. Overall, it was a successful meet for the home nations.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Gardener won a double gold medal (60m) for Britain at the Glasgow 2018 Commonwealth Games, where she finished second behind her teammate Nick Smith and third behind Daniel Persson and Luca Verdecchia. Her times of 6.61 and 6.62 seconds were well short of her Olympic record of 6.39secs, but she attributed the success to careful training and a strong race fitness. She hopes to improve on these times by joining the World Indoor Championships soon.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Britain's Jason Gardener wins double gold at the Norwich Union International, including a 60m win ahead of Nick Smith and Daniel Persson, while Maduaka takes the women's 60m race in 7.23 seconds, Russia dominating with nine points ahead of Britain in third place.
qwen2.5:3b:
Jason Gardener won double victories in the 60m race at the Norwich Union International, improving his performance from the Olympics where he won gold with the 100m relay team. He finished second in the second round despite a poor start but still beat Daniel Persson and Luca Verdecchia. 

In the women's events, Maduaka won the 60m race but was unable to replicate her success in the 200m where she placed fourth. Britain came in third overall with Russia topping the standings.

Russia dominated the high jump event, surpassing Stefan Holm’s unbeaten record. The men's triple jump and pole vault also saw Russian dominance. 

In the women's events, Russia emerged victorious in 800m and 400m races, while Italy claimed a first win in the men's 1500m event. France won both the men's and women’s 400m races.
opencoder:1.5b: Gardener wins double in Glasgow, Britain's Jason Gardener enjoyed a double 60m success in Glasgow in his first competitive outing since he won 100m relay gold at the Athens Olympics. His times were well short of American Maurice Greene's 60m world record of 6.39secs from 1998. "It's a very hard record to break, but I believe I've trained very well," said the world indoor champion, who hopes to get closer to the mark this season.
smollm:1.7b: The Gardener won a double in Glasgow by winning both the 60m and 100m races in the same season, beating Scotland's Jason Gardener in the process.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>

The user provided some detailed information, including the times he achieved, how he overcame his initial struggles, and what he learned.

First, I should read through the entire text carefully to understand all the key points. It mentions Gardener's double success, which included a 60m relay in Greece, beating both Nick Smith there and Daniel Persson in Norway, and then defeating Swede Luca Verdecchia in a second race. His times were very fast, just short of the world record. He also had some personal reflections about training.

Then, the text talks about other athletes from the UK, like Maduaka, who was the double Olympic champion, and how they did in various races. Some British competitors had setbacks, like Jade Johnson missing a jump because her back injury started an issue. Russia also had successful performances in high jump, triple jump, pole vault, and 400m.

The user wants me to create a concise summary that captures the main ideas without adding any extra information or explanations. So I need to pick out the most important parts: Gardener's double success, his race details, how he trained, and the reactions of the athletes on both sides.

I should make sure to include key moments like his 60m relay win in Greece, beating Nick Smith, Daniel Persson, and Luca Verdecchia. Also, mention his personal achievements, like finishing just short of the world record, but training hard, expecting improvement, etc.

Additionally, I need to highlight Russia's major shock with their double Olympic champion and their performance in other races, including high jump, triple jump, pole vault, and 400m. The British team's strong performances in both high jump, pole vault, and women's 800m are also important points.

I should structure the summary to flow from Gardener's success, his training approach, Russia's achievements, and how the rest of the world reacted. This will make it clear and concise, covering all the essential information without unnecessary details.
</think>

Jason Gardener secured double Olympic success in Glasgow and Norway by leading a thrilling 60m relay victory in Greece, defeating Nick Smith, Daniel Persson, and Luca Verdecchia with exceptional speeds under 6 seconds. His training emphasized recovery and race fitness, aiming to approach closer to the world record this season.  

Russia also made significant strides: Maduaka claimed double Olympic success, edge out Russia's Fedorova and Sweden's Kallur in a women's 60m race, and secured another win in 7.23secs for Russia, while Kallur came fourth. The British quartet fell to Russia's new world record in the 200m.  

Jade Johnson faced a setback due to her back injury, losing in the long jump. Russia won the meeting with their high jump victory, ending Russia's unbeaten record. Britain secured major achievements: second place in the high jump, fourth in pole vault, and third in women's 800m, while France claimed the men's 400m.
tinyllama:1.1b: In Glasgow, Britain's Jason Gardener won a double gold medal in the invitational race at the Norwich Union International. Gardeners' times of 6.61 and 6.62 seconds were well short of his American counterpart Maurice Greene's 60m world record from 1998. He beat Swede Daniel Persson and Italian Lucca Verdica in the first race, but lost to American Maurice Greene's new world record in the second race. Despite missing out on a podium place, Gardeners' setback did not affect his overall performance as he won all four events contested at the International.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Scotland's Jason Gardener, a double gold medalist at the Athens Olympics, won a thrilling double 60m victory in Glasgow. Britain's Jason Gardener also won the men's triple jump, with Tosin Oke taking silver and Nick Buckfield finishing fourth. British women's 800m winner Jenny Meadows claimed third place in a nail-biting finish. Chris Lambert had to settle for fourth place after fading in the final stages of the men's 200m race. Britain's Brett Rund secured their win in the women's 60m hurdles, with Irina Shevchenko taking silver and Sarah Claxton finishing in fourth place. Finally, the Italians claimed victory in the men's 1500m final with a strong finish from Australia's Luke Durstone.
phi:2.7b: The text summarizes Jason Gardener's successful first competitive outing since winning the 100m relay at the Athens Olympics, where he won a double gold medal and improved his personal best time. He also competed in two invitational races, winning one of them and coming second in the other. He hopes to get closer to the world record set by American Maurice Greene. The text also mentions some other British achievements, such as Jade Johnson's fourth-place finish in the long jump, and Chris Lambert's third-place finish in the 200m race.
orca-mini:3b: Gardener won a double in Glasgow, winning the invitational race at Norwich Union International and then beating Sweden's Daniel Persson and Italy's Luca Verdecchia to win the 60m race. His times of 6.61 and 6.62 seconds were well short of American Maurice Greene's 60m world record of 6.39secs from 1998, but he hopes to get closer to that mark this season.
hermes3:3b:
Jason Gardener won 2 golds for Britain in Glasgow Olympics debut, while Darrell
Emmerson also secured a double in Glasgow. Gardener achieved times of 6.61 and
6.62 seconds, short of Maurice Greene's world record. Maduaka won 100m, while Jade
Johnson missed long jump due to back injury. Other notable winners include:
- Toldya Shcherbakov (high jump)
- Trecia Smith-Swain (triple jump)
- Tim Lobinger (pole vault)
- Natalya Toronskaya (800m hurdles) and Mounir Larmhi (1500m).
stablelm-zephyr:3b: British athlete Jason Gardener won a double 60m race at the Norwich Union International in Glasgow, beating Nick Smith and Daniel Persson. He hopes to break the 60m world record this season. Briton Daley Thompson won the high jump and the triple jump, while Russia's Tatiana Gutsukhina took victory in the women's 60m hurdles and pole vault for women. For the men, Sweden won the 1500m, 800m, 200m, 400m, and 4x200m relay, while Britain won a mixed 4x400m relay and France won a mixed 4x800m relay.
stablelm2:1.6b: British gardener Jason Gardener wins double races in Glasgow, including an invitational race where he won ahead of Scottish competitor Nick Smith. He then recovers from a poor start in another event by beating Swedish competitor Daniel Persson and Italy's Luca Verdecchia. His times for both races were short of American Maurice Greene's world record. Double Olympic champion won the women's 200m race, while Britain's Jade Johnson suffered a recurrence of her back injury during the long jump. Russia won the event with the highest total points, followed by Britain in second place and France in third.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
British athletes dominated a track meet in Glasgow, winning nine of the 10 events against international competitors. Jason Gardener achieved a double 60m success (6.61 and 6.62 seconds), expressing confidence in approaching the world record despite its challenging nature. Britain's Jade Edwards won the women's 60m (7.23 seconds) and was part of a fourth-place relay team that set a new world indoor record for Russia. The men's pole vault was won by Chris Brown (5.65m), while Tosin Oke (15.80m) placed fourth for Britain.

Russia secured the overall victory with 63 points, followed by Britain (48 points), and France (47 points). Notable individual achievements included Russia's Nikolay Voytenko breaking Olympic champion Stefan Holm's long-standing unbeaten record in high jump. In the women's 800m, Jenny Meadows finished third for Britain. Sweden claimed wins in men's 1500m and 60m hurdles, while France secured victories in men's 400m and 200m events. Italy emerged as the first winners in men's 1500m, with James Thie placing fourth for Britain.
